vWashington House Rabbit Newsv

Volume 7  Issue 1 March 1998


FERAL RABBIT RESCUE ENDS

An Update to the Redmond Rabbit Rescue
By Jill Tamane

With much disappointment and frustration, the rescue project to save the Redmond feral rabbit colony from ongoing construction in a business park is defeated.

It has been exactly one year since the start of communications with Eddie Bauer (Redmond) to initiate the relocation of a large feral rabbit colony from the business park. Time was crucial. The lives of several hundred rabbits were in constant jeopardy because of construction and development at the site. In addition, the colony’s population continued to increase fueled by people who disregarded "no dumping/feeding" signs and were observed feeding the rabbits nonessential "junk" foods (basic biology declares that the abundance of food allows for reproduction at a higher rate, dramatically increasing a species’ population). People were also observed dumping unwanted pet bunnies at the site.

Despite what looked like a promising beginning to a huge project, HRS has found it to be a year of continuous resistance; refusal to accept responsibility; and finally, recognition that the goals of HRS were not compatible to those of Eddie Bauer, and therefore were unattainable.

HRS dealt with four entirely different volunteer groups since the start of the project. Each group claimed to represent Eddie Bauer, but yet presented an entirely contrasting agenda and focus as the previous group. By January, frustration was settling in as a retrospective view by HRS showed very little results for the amount of effort involved as only a little more than 100 rabbits were rescued after a nine month period. This prompted HRS to require Eddie Bauer’s commitment in writing. Eddie Bauer agreed. "It turned out that the joke was on us, as after two months of time wasted to prepare a document that everyone would agree on, Eddie Bauer would not sign the document, nor would they honor it," says Washington HRS President, Sandi Ackerman. "It’s obvious that our goal of relocating all rabbits was not the same as theirs."

The four page "Hare Transplant Project Agreement" drawn-up by HRS and Eddie Bauer, stated its overall mission as follows: "Volunteers and businesses along the east side of 148th Avenue Northeast, between SR 520 and Northeast 40th Street, will work together to humanely relocate all neighborhood feral rabbits in 1998." Specific responsibilities would be divided among HRS, Eddie Bauer, Redmond neighborhood volunteers, and King County Animal Control. However, Eddie Bauer would not sign the agreement, claiming they did not sign documents, but rather operated on a "handshake," which—to them— was more valuable than a signature. The project was defeated two days later when an HRS rabbit was removed from the shelter in direct violation of the unsigned agreement. It became obvious that this piece of paper, without signatures, was worth exactly nothing, so HRS—with much disappointment—terminated the project. Eddie Bauer ordered HRS to "take all HRS property out of shelter by Monday, March 23, 1998."

Removing the property would not come easily. During a morning stop at the Eddie Bauer rabbit shelter to remove HRS property, Sandi Ackerman was stopped by Redmond Police officers crouched behind her van with guns drawn and pointed at her. An unknown employee at Eddie Bauer had called the police about "three men who had broken the lock of the shelter and were in the process of loading their van with stolen property." After realizing the situation at hand did not coincide with the call, the Redmond Police officers thought they had arrived at the wrong location and left a traumatized Sandi to continue. They returned minutes later with the Eddie Bauer security officer who was not notified that Sandi and HRS were told to remove shelter property with only a few days notice. "That final experience epitomized the whole frustrating year of dealing with Eddie Bauer and their lack of communication, commitment, and goals within their own company."

An unknown number of rabbits remain in jeopardy at the site. Liver coccidia continues to kill the rabbits and to contaminate newly dumped rabbits. In addition to the continued construction, predators abound in the area. Sandi states, "I left the shelter after midnight one night and stood silently as a coyote stared brazenly back at me. Hawks pickup rabbits to about 20 feet then drop them, they do this over and over until the animal is stunned or dead. There is plenty of food for these predators living right in the middle of a busy business park. I don’t object to these wild animals finding food for themselves, but they should be finding wild food, not domestic rabbits to feast upon."

In the last written communication to Eddie Bauer, Sandi Ackerman stated: "HRS has done everything that was promised (and that we put into writing and signed) to the point that Eddie Bauer would renege and instruct us to halt everything." Sadly, it is the rabbits who will continue to suffer. v
